text: [Music]
Hi, I'm Tim and this is my pronunciation
workshop. Here I'm going to show you how
English is really spoken. Come on, let's
go
[Music]
inside. Where were you born? Where do
you come from? Here's what we heard when
we asked some people in London their
names and where they come from. Uh, my
name is Charlotte and I'm from Darwin in
Lanasher. My name's Ollie and I'm from
Norolk. I'm Amy from London. Ally, I'm
from Northern Ireland. My name's
Victoria. I'm from Cambridge. Now, they
all used the word from, didn't they? But
they didn't pronounce it from. Listen
again. How is it pronounced? Uh, my
name's Charlotte and I'm from Darwin in
Lanasher. My name's Ollie and I'm from
Norolk. I'm Amy from London. Alli, I'm
from Northern Ireland. My name's
Victoria. I'm from Cambridge. The word
from is a preposition. It's usually not
that important in a sentence. So, it's
often unstressed. Now, at the end of the
question, where do you come from? It's
unstressed, but the pronunciation is
still from. However, when it's
unstressed and it comes in the middle of
the sentence, the O changes to schwah.
So, from becomes from. This is an
example of a weak form. And here are
some more examples.
I borrowed it from my brother. I read
the book from cover to cover.
The nearest post office is not far from
here. Come over anytime from 7:00.
Right. So, you've heard the examples and
now it's your turn. You know the drill
by now. Listen and repeat. I borrowed it
from my brother.
I read the book from cover to cover.
The nearest post office is not far from
here.
Come over anytime from 7:00.
Well done. Now remember, if you want to
learn more about pronunciation, then
please visit our website
bbclearningenglish.com. And that is
about it from the pronunciation workshop
for this week. I'll see you soon.
Bye-bye. Now, you know me, I am a
skilled craftsman, an artisan, if you
will. I like to work with my hands. So,
I'm looking forward to a little bit of
DIY this
afternoon.
Actually, on second thoughts, I think
I've learned from my
mistakes. Let's put this down
here. Ouch.
[Music]
